description: Azure Pipelines predefined variables reference. These variables are automatically set by the system and are read-only (except Build.Clean and System.Debug). In YAML pipelines, variable names become environment variables with uppercase names and dots replaced by underscores (e.g. Build.SourceBranch → BUILD_SOURCEBRANCH).

agent.title: Agent Variables
agent.description: Variables related to the build/release agent.

variables.name: Agent.BuildDirectory
variables.description: Local path on the agent where all folders for a given build pipeline are created.

variables.name: Agent.ContainerMapping
variables.description: A mapping from container resource names in the pipeline to their Docker IDs at runtime.

variables.name: Agent.HomeDirectory
variables.description: The directory the agent is installed into.

variables.name: Agent.Id
variables.description: The ID of the agent.

variables.name: Agent.JobName
variables.description: The name of the running job (e.g. 'Job' or '__default').

variables.name: Agent.JobStatus
variables.description: The status of the build. Succeeded, SucceededWithIssues, Failed, Canceled, Skipped.

variables.name: Agent.MachineName
variables.description: The name of the machine on which the agent is installed.

variables.name: Agent.Name
variables.description: The name of the agent as registered with the pool.

variables.name: Agent.OS
variables.description: The operating system of the agent host. Windows_NT, Darwin, or Linux.

variables.name: Agent.OSArchitecture
variables.description: The operating system processor architecture of the agent host. X86, X64, or ARM.

variables.name: Agent.TempDirectory
variables.description: A temporary folder that is cleaned after each pipeline job.

variables.name: Agent.ToolsDirectory
variables.description: The directory used by tasks such as Node Tool Installer and Use Python Version.

variables.name: Agent.WorkFolder
variables.description: The working directory for this agent.

build.title: Build Variables
build.description: Variables containing information about the build.

variables.name: Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory
variables.description: Local path on the agent for storing artifacts before publishing. Cleaned before each build.

variables.name: Build.BuildId
variables.description: The ID of the record for the completed build.

variables.name: Build.BuildNumber
variables.description: The name of the completed build (run number). You can specify the format in pipeline options.

variables.name: Build.BuildUri
variables.description: The URI for the build. E.g. vstfs:///Build/Build/1430.

variables.name: Build.BinariesDirectory
variables.description: Local path on the agent for creating output binaries.

variables.name: Build.ContainerId
variables.description: The ID of the container for your artifact.

variables.name: Build.CronSchedule.DisplayName
variables.description: The displayName of the cron schedule that triggered the pipeline run.

variables.name: Build.DefinitionName
variables.description: The name of the build pipeline.

variables.name: Build.DefinitionVersion
variables.description: The version of the build pipeline.

variables.name: Build.QueuedBy
variables.description: The display name of the identity that queued the build. Trigger-dependent.

variables.name: Build.QueuedById
variables.description: The ID of the identity that queued the build.

variables.name: Build.Reason
variables.description: The event that caused the build: Manual, IndividualCI, BatchedCI, Schedule, ValidateShelveset, CheckInShelveset, PullRequest, BuildCompletion, ResourceTrigger.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Clean
variables.description: The value you've selected for Clean in the source repository settings.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Id
variables.description: The unique identifier of the repository.

variables.name: Build.Repository.LocalPath
variables.description: Local path on the agent where source code files are downloaded. Alias: Build.SourcesDirectory.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Name
variables.description: The name of the triggering repository.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Provider
variables.description: The type of repository: TfsGit, TfsVersionControl, Git, GitHub, Svn.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Uri
variables.description: The URL for the triggering repository.

variables.name: Build.RequestedFor
variables.description: The display name of the identity that triggered (requested) the build.

variables.name: Build.RequestedForEmail
variables.description: The email of the identity that triggered the build.

variables.name: Build.RequestedForId
variables.description: The ID of the identity that triggered the build.

variables.name: Build.SourceBranch
variables.description: The branch that triggered the build. For pull requests, this is the merge branch.

variables.name: Build.SourceBranchName
variables.description: The name of the branch (last path segment). For refs/heads/main → main.

variables.name: Build.SourceVersion
variables.description: The latest version control change (commit SHA) included in this build.

variables.name: Build.SourceVersionMessage
variables.description: The comment of the commit that triggered the build. Truncated to first line.

variables.name: Build.SourcesDirectory
variables.description: Local path on the agent where source code files are downloaded.

variables.name: Build.StagingDirectory
variables.description: Alias for Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.BuildId
variables.description: If the build was triggered by another build, the BuildId of the triggering build.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.DefinitionId
variables.description: If the build was triggered by another build, the DefinitionId of the triggering build.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.DefinitionName
variables.description: If the build was triggered by another build, the name of the triggering build pipeline.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.BuildNumber
variables.description: If the build was triggered by another build, the number of the triggering build.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.ProjectID
variables.description: If the build was triggered by another build, the ID of the project that contains the triggering build.

variables.name: System.AccessToken
variables.description: OAuth token to access the Azure DevOps REST API. Use $(System.AccessToken) in scripts. Must be explicitly mapped.

variables.name: System.CollectionId
variables.description: The GUID of the TFS collection or Azure DevOps organization.

variables.name: System.CollectionUri
variables.description: The URI of the TFS collection or Azure DevOps organization.

variables.name: System.Debug
variables.description: Set to 'true' to enable verbose logging. This is the only settable system variable.

variables.name: System.DefaultWorkingDirectory
variables.description: Local path on the agent where source code files are downloaded.

variables.name: System.DefinitionId
variables.description: The ID of the build pipeline.

variables.name: System.HostType
variables.description: Whether the pipeline is running as a build or a release: build, deployment, release.

variables.name: System.IsScheduled
variables.description: True if the build was triggered by a schedule.

variables.name: System.JobAttempt
variables.description: Set to 1 the first time a job is attempted, increments each time the job is retried.

variables.name: System.JobDisplayName
variables.description: The human-readable name of the current job.

variables.name: System.JobId
variables.description: A unique identifier for a single attempt of a single job.

variables.name: System.JobName
variables.description: The name of the job, typically used for expressing dependencies.

variables.name: System.PhaseAttempt
variables.description: Set to 1 the first time a phase is attempted, increments on retry.

variables.name: System.PhaseName
variables.description: The name of the phase.

variables.name: System.PlanId
variables.description: An internal identifier for a pipeline run.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.IsFork
variables.description: True if the pull request is from a fork of the repository.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.PullRequestId
variables.description: The ID of the pull request (Azure Repos).

variables.name: System.PullRequest.PullRequestNumber
variables.description: The number of the pull request (GitHub).

variables.name: System.PullRequest.SourceBranch
variables.description: The source branch of the pull request.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.SourceRepositoryURI
variables.description: The URL of the source repository for the pull request.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.TargetBranch
variables.description: The target branch of the pull request.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.TargetBranchName
variables.description: The short name (last segment) of the target branch.

variables.name: System.StageAttempt
variables.description: Set to 1 the first time a stage is attempted, increments on retry.

variables.name: System.StageDisplayName
variables.description: The human-readable name of the current stage.

variables.name: System.StageName
variables.description: The name of the stage.

variables.name: System.TeamFoundationCollectionUri
variables.description: The URI of the TFS collection or Azure DevOps organization. Alias for System.CollectionUri.

variables.name: System.TeamProject
variables.description: The name of the project.

variables.name: System.TeamProjectId
variables.description: The ID of the project.

variables.name: System.TimelineId
variables.description: An internal identifier for the timeline of the pipeline run.

pipeline.title: Pipeline Variables
pipeline.description: Variables related to the pipeline workspace.

variables.name: Pipeline.Workspace
variables.description: Workspace directory for a particular pipeline. Same as Agent.BuildDirectory.

variables.name: Environment.Name
variables.description: Name of the environment targeted in the deployment job.

variables.name: Environment.Id
variables.description: ID of the environment targeted in the deployment job.

variables.name: Environment.ResourceName
variables.description: Name of the specific resource within the environment targeted.

variables.name: Environment.ResourceId
variables.description: ID of the specific resource within the environment targeted.

variables.name: Strategy.Name
variables.description: Name of the deployment strategy: canary, runOnce, or rolling.

variables.name: Strategy.CycleName
variables.description: The current cycle name: PreIteration, Iteration, or PostIteration.

checks.title: Checks Variables
checks.description: Variables for approval and check conditions.

variables.name: Checks.StageAttempt
variables.description: Set to 1 the first time a stage is attempted. Incremented each time a stage is retried. Use in approval and check conditions.

variables.name: Agent.BuildDirectory
variables.description: The local path on the agent where all folders for a given build pipeline are created. This variable has the same value as `Pipeline.Workspace`. For example: `/home/vsts/work/1`. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

variables.name: Agent.ContainerMapping
variables.description:
A mapping from container resource names in YAML to their Docker IDs at runtime.

Example follows table.

variables.name: Agent.HomeDirectory
variables.description: The directory the agent is installed into. This variable contains the agent software. For example: `c:\agent`. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

variables.name: Agent.Id
variables.description: The ID of the agent.

variables.name: Agent.JobName
variables.description: The name of the running job. This name is usually `Job`; or `__default`, but in multi-config scenarios, it's the configuration.

variables.name: Agent.JobStatus
variables.description:
The status of the build.
  • `Canceled`
  • `Failed`
  • `Succeeded`
  • `SucceededWithIssues` (partially successful)
  • `Skipped` (last job)
The environment variable should be referenced as `AGENT_JOBSTATUS`. The older `agent.jobstatus` is available for backwards compatibility.

variables.name: Agent.MachineName
variables.description: The name of the machine on which the agent is installed.

variables.name: Agent.Name
variables.description:
The name of the agent that is registered with the pool.

If you're using a self-hosted agent, you specify the name. See [agents](../../agents/agents.md).

variables.name: Agent.OS
variables.description:
The operating system of the agent host. Valid values are:
  • `Windows_NT`
  • `Darwin`
  • `Linux`
If you're running in a container, the agent host and container can run different operating systems.

variables.name: Agent.OSArchitecture
variables.description:
The operating system processor architecture of the agent host. Valid values are:
  • `X86`
  • `X64`
  • `ARM`

variables.name: Agent.TempDirectory
variables.description:
A temporary folder that is cleaned after each pipeline job. This directory is used by tasks such as [.NET Core CLI task](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/dotnet-core-cli-v2) to hold temporary items like test results before they're published.

For example: `/home/vsts/work/_temp` for Ubuntu.

variables.name: Agent.ToolsDirectory
variables.description:
The directory used by tasks such as [Node Tool Installer](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/node-tool-v0) and [Use Python Version](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/use-python-version-v0) to switch between multiple versions of a tool.

These tasks add tools from this directory to `PATH` so that subsequent build steps can use them.

Learn about [managing this directory on a self-hosted agent](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2008884).

variables.name: Agent.WorkFolder
variables.description:
The working directory for this agent.

For example: `c:\agent_work`.

Note: This directory isn't guaranteed to be writable by pipeline tasks (for example, when mapped into a container). For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

variables.name: Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory
variables.description:
The local path on the agent where any artifacts are copied to before being pushed to their destination. For example: `c:\agent_work\1\a`.

A typical way to use this folder is to publish your build artifacts with the [Copy files](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/copy-files-v2) and [Publish build artifacts](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/publish-build-artifacts-v1) tasks.

Note: Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory and Build.StagingDirectory are interchangeable. This directory is purged before each new build, so you don't have to clean it up yourself.

See [Artifacts in Azure Pipelines](../../artifacts/artifacts-overview.md). For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.BuildId
variables.description: The ID of the record for the completed build.

variables.name: Build.BuildNumber
variables.description:
The name of the completed build, also known as the run number. You can specify [what is included](../../process/run-number.md) in this value.

A typical use of this variable is to make it part of the label format, which you specify on the [repository tab](../../repos/index.md).

Note: This value can contain whitespace or other invalid label characters. In these cases, the [label format](../../../repos/tfvc/labels-command.md) fails.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.BuildUri
variables.description:
The URI for the build. For example: `vstfs:///Build/Build/1430`.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.BinariesDirectory
variables.description:
The local path on the agent you can use as an output folder for compiled binaries.

On self-hosted agents, new build pipelines aren't set up to clean this directory by default. You can define your build to clean it up on the [Repository tab](../../repos/index.md).

For example: `c:\agent_work\1\b`. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.ContainerId
variables.description: The ID of the container for your artifact. When you upload an artifact in your pipeline, it's added to a container that is specific for that particular artifact.

variables.name: Build.CronSchedule.DisplayName
variables.description: The `displayName` of the cron schedule that triggered the pipeline run. This variable is only set if a YAML scheduled trigger triggers the pipeline run. For more information, see [schedules.cron definition - Build.CronSchedule.DisplayName variable](/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema/schedules-cron#buildcronscheduledisplayname-variable)

variables.name: Build.DefinitionName
variables.description:
The name of the build pipeline.

Note: This value can contain whitespace or other invalid label characters. In these cases, the [label format](../../../repos/tfvc/labels-command.md) fails.

variables.name: Build.DefinitionVersion
variables.description: The version of the build pipeline.

variables.name: Build.QueuedBy
variables.description:
See [How are the identity variables set?](#identity_values).

Note: This value can contain whitespace or other invalid label characters. In these cases, the [label format](../../../repos/tfvc/labels-command.md) fails.

variables.name: Build.QueuedById
variables.description: See [How are the identity variables set?](#identity_values).

variables.name: Build.Reason
variables.description:
The event that caused the build to run.
  • `Manual`: A user manually queued the build.
  • `IndividualCI`: **Continuous integration (CI)** triggered by a Git push or a Team Foundation Version Control (TFVC) check-in.
  • `BatchedCI`: **Continuous integration (CI)** triggered by a Git push or a TFVC check-in, and the **Batch changes** was selected.
  • `Schedule`: **Scheduled** trigger.
  • `ValidateShelveset`: A user manually queued the build of a specific TFVC shelveset.
  • `CheckInShelveset`: **Gated check-in** trigger.
  • `PullRequest`: A Git branch policy that requires a build triggers the build.
  • `BuildCompletion`: [Another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build.
  • `ResourceTrigger`: [A resource trigger](../../process/resources.md) or [another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build.
See [Build pipeline triggers](../triggers.md), [Improve code quality with branch policies](../../../repos/git/branch-policies.md).

variables.name: Build.Repository.Clean
variables.description:
The value you selected for **Clean** in the [source repository settings](../../repos/index.md).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.Repository.LocalPath
variables.description:
The local path on the agent where your source code files are downloaded. For example: `c:\agent_work\1\s`.

On self-hosted agents, new build pipelines update only the changed files by default. You can modify how files are downloaded on the [Repository tab](../../repos/index.md).

Important note: If you check out only one Git repository, this path is the exact path to the code.

If you check out multiple repositories, the behavior is as follows (and might differ from the value of the Build.SourcesDirectory variable):
  • If the checkout step for the self (primary) repository has no custom checkout path defined, or the checkout path is the multi-checkout default path `$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s/&` for the self repository, the value of this variable reverts to its default value, which is `$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s`.
  • If the checkout step for the self (primary) repository had a custom checkout path defined that is not its multi-checkout default path, this variable contains the exact path to the self repository.
This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.Repository.ID
variables.description:
The unique identifier of the [repository](../../repos/index.md).

This value doesn't change, even if the name of the repository does.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Name
variables.description: The name of the triggering [repository](../../repos/index.md).

variables.name: Build.Repository.Provider
variables.description:
The type of the triggering [repository](../../repos/index.md).
  • `TfsGit`: [TFS Git repository](../../../repos/git/index.yml)
  • `TfsVersionControl`: [Team Foundation Version Control](../../../repos/tfvc/what-is-tfvc.md)
  • `Git`: Git repository hosted on an external server
  • `GitHub`
  • `Svn`: Subversion
This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Tfvc.Workspace
variables.description:
Defined if your [repository](../../repos/index.md) is Team Foundation Version Control. The name of the [TFVC workspace](../../../repos/tfvc/create-work-workspaces.md) used by the build agent.

For example, if the Agent.BuildDirectory is `c:\agent_work\12` and the Agent.Id is `8`, the workspace name could be: `ws_12_8`

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Uri
variables.description:
The URL for the triggering repository. For example:
  • Git: [https://fabrikamfiber@dev.azure.com/fabrikamfiber/_git/Scripts](https://fabrikamfiber@dev.azure.com/fabrikamfiber/_git/Scripts)
  • TFVC: [https://dev.azure.com/fabrikamfiber/](https://dev.azure.com/fabrikamfiber/)
This variable can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.RequestedFor
variables.description:
See [How are the identity variables set?](#identity_values).

Note: This value can contain whitespace or other invalid label characters. In these cases, the [label format](../../../repos/tfvc/labels-command.md) fails.

variables.name: Build.RequestedForEmail
variables.description: See [How are the identity variables set?](#identity_values).

variables.name: Build.RequestedForId
variables.description: See [How are the identity variables set?](#identity_values).

variables.name: Build.SourceBranch
variables.description:
The branch of the triggering repo the build was queued for. Some examples:
  • Git repo branch: `refs/heads/main`
  • Git repo pull request: `refs/pull/1/merge`
  • TFVC repo branch: `$/teamproject/main`
  • TFVC repo gated check-in: `Gated_2016-06-06_05.20.51.4369;username@live.com`
  • TFVC repo shelveset build: `myshelveset;username@live.com`
  • When a tag triggers your pipeline: `refs/tags/your-tag-name`
When you use this variable in your build number format, the forward slash characters (`/`) are replaced with underscore characters (`_`).

Note: In TFVC, if you're running a gated check-in build or manually building a shelveset, you can't use this variable in your build number format.

variables.name: Build.SourceBranchName
variables.description:
The name of the branch in the triggering repo the build was queued for.
  • Git repo branch, pull request, or tag: The last path segment in the ref. For example, in `refs/heads/main` this value is `main`. In `refs/heads/feature/tools`, this value is `tools`. In `refs/tags/your-tag-name`, the value is `your_tag_name`, with hyphens (`-`) replaced by underscores (`_`).
  • TFVC repo branch: The last path segment in the root server path for the workspace. For example, in `$/teamproject/main` this value is `main`.
  • TFVC repo gated check-in or shelveset build is the name of the shelveset. For example, `Gated_2016-06-06_05.20.51.4369;username@live.com` or `myshelveset;username@live.com`.
Note: In TFVC, if you're running a gated check-in build or manually building a shelveset, you can't use this variable in your build number format.

variables.name: Build.SourcesDirectory
variables.description:
The local path on the agent where your source code files are downloaded. For example: `c:\agent_work\1\s`.

On self-hosted agents, new build pipelines update only the changed files. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

Important note: If you check out only one Git repository, this path is the exact path to the code. If you check out multiple repositories, it reverts to its default value, which is `$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s`, even if the self (primary) repository is checked out to a custom path different from its multi-checkout default path `$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s/` (in this respect, the variable differs from the behavior of the Build.Repository.LocalPath variable).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.SourceVersion
variables.description:
The latest version control change of the triggering repo that is included in this build.
  • Git: The [commit](../../../repos/git/commits.md) ID.
  • TFVC: the [changeset](../../../repos/tfvc/find-view-changesets.md).
This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.SourceVersionMessage
variables.description:
The comment of the commit or changeset for the triggering repo. We truncate the message to the first line or 200 characters, whichever is shorter.

The `Build.SourceVersionMessage` corresponds to the message on `Build.SourceVersion` commit. The `Build.SourceVersion` commit for a PR build is the merge commit (not the commit on the source branch).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

Also, this variable is only available on the step level and isn't available in the job or stage levels. That is, the message isn't extracted until the job starts and the code is checked out.

Note: The **Build.SourceVersionMessage** variable doesn't work with classic build pipelines in Bitbucket repositories when **Batch changes while a build is in progress** is enabled.

variables.name: Build.StageRequestedBy
variables.description:
The person who triggered the stage when the stage runs manually, or `Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.TFS` otherwise.

Note: This value can contain whitespace or other invalid label characters.

variables.name: Build.StageRequestedForId
variables.description: The GUID of identity of the person who triggered the stage when the stage runs manually, or `00000002-0000-8888-8000-000000000000` otherwise.

variables.name: Build.StagingDirectory
variables.description:
The local path on the agent where any artifacts are copied to before being pushed to their destination. For example: `c:\agent_work\1\a`. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

A typical way to use this folder is to publish your build artifacts with the [Copy files](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/copy-files-v2) and [Publish build artifacts](/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/reference/publish-build-artifacts-v1) tasks.

Note: Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory and Build.StagingDirectory are interchangeable. This directory is purged before each new build, so you don't have to clean it up yourself.

See [Artifacts in Azure Pipelines](../../artifacts/artifacts-overview.md).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.Repository.Git.SubmoduleCheckout
variables.description:
The value you selected for **Checkout submodules** on the [repository tab](../../repos/index.md). With multiple repos checked out, this value tracks the triggering repository's setting.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Build.SourceTfvcShelveset
variables.description:
Defined if your [repository](../../repos/index.md) is Team Foundation Version Control.

If you're running a [gated build](../../repos/tfvc.md#gated) or a [shelveset build](../../create-first-pipeline.md#queueabuild), this variable is set to the name of the [shelveset](../../../repos/tfvc/suspend-your-work-manage-your-shelvesets.md) you're building.

Note: This variable yields a value that is invalid for build use in a build number format.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.BuildId
variables.description:
If [another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build, then this variable is set to the BuildID of the triggering build. In Classic pipelines, a build completion trigger triggers this variable.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

If you're triggering a YAML pipeline using `resources`, you should use the [resources variables](/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema/resources-pipelines-pipeline#the-pipeline-resource-metadata-as-predefined-variables) instead.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.DefinitionId
variables.description:
If [another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build, then this variable is set to the DefinitionID of the triggering build. In Classic pipelines, a build completion trigger triggers this variable.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

If you're triggering a YAML pipeline using `resources`, you should use the [resources variables](/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema/resources-pipelines-pipeline#the-pipeline-resource-metadata-as-predefined-variables) instead.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.DefinitionName
variables.description:
If [another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build, then this variable is set to the name of the triggering build pipeline. In Classic pipelines, a build completion trigger triggers this variable.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

If you're triggering a YAML pipeline using `resources`, you should use the [resources variables](/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema/resources-pipelines-pipeline#the-pipeline-resource-metadata-as-predefined-variables) instead.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.BuildNumber
variables.description:
If [another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build, then this variable is set to the number of the triggering build. In Classic pipelines, a build completion trigger triggers this variable.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

If you're triggering a YAML pipeline using `resources`, you should use the [resources variables](/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema/resources-pipelines-pipeline#the-pipeline-resource-metadata-as-predefined-variables) instead.

variables.name: Build.TriggeredBy.ProjectID
variables.description:
If [another build triggers](../../process/pipeline-triggers.md) the build, then this variable is set to ID of the project that contains the triggering build. In Classic pipelines, a build completion trigger triggers this variable.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

If you're triggering a YAML pipeline using `resources`, you should use the [resources variables](/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema/resources-pipelines-pipeline#the-pipeline-resource-metadata-as-predefined-variables) instead.

variables.name: Common.TestResultsDirectory
variables.description:
The local path on the agent where the test results are created. For example: `c:\agent_work\1\TestResults`. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Pipeline.Workspace
variables.description: Workspace directory for a particular pipeline. This variable has the same value as `Agent.BuildDirectory`. For example, `/home/vsts/work/1`. For more information about the agent directory structure, see [Agent directory structure](../../agents/agents.md#agent-directory-structure).

variables.name: Environment.Name
variables.description: Name of the environment targeted in the deployment job to run the deployment steps and record the deployment history. For example, `smarthotel-dev`.

variables.name: Environment.Id
variables.description: ID of the environment targeted in the deployment job. For example, `10`.

variables.name: Environment.ResourceName
variables.description: Name of the specific resource within the environment targeted in the deployment job to run the deployment steps and record the deployment history. For example, `bookings` which is a Kubernetes namespace that is added as a resource to the environment `smarthotel-dev`.

variables.name: Environment.ResourceId
variables.description: ID of the specific resource within the environment targeted in the deployment job to run the deployment steps. For example, `4`.

variables.name: Strategy.Name
variables.description: The name of the deployment strategy: `canary`, `runOnce`, or `rolling`.

variables.name: Strategy.CycleName
variables.description: The current cycle name in a deployment. Options are `PreIteration`, `Iteration`, or `PostIteration`.

variables.name: System.AccessToken
variables.description:
[Use the OAuth token to access the REST API](../../scripts/powershell.md#example-powershell-script-access-rest-api).

[Use System.AccessToken from YAML scripts](../variables.md#systemaccesstoken).

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: System.CollectionId
variables.description: The GUID of the Azure DevOps organization or collection.

variables.name: System.CollectionUri
variables.description: The URI of the Azure DevOps organization or collection. For example: `https://dev.azure.com/fabrikamfiber/`.

variables.name: System.DefaultWorkingDirectory
variables.description: [!INCLUDE [include](../includes/variables-build-sources-directory.md)]

variables.name: System.DefinitionId
variables.description: The ID of the build pipeline.

variables.name: System.HostType
variables.description: Set to `build` if the pipeline is a build. For a release, the values are `deployment` for a Deployment group job, `gates` during evaluation of gates, and `release` for other (Agent and Agentless) jobs.

variables.name: System.JobAttempt
variables.description: Set to 1 the first time this job is attempted, and increments every time the job is retried.

variables.name: System.JobDisplayName
variables.description: The human-readable name given to a job.

variables.name: System.JobId
variables.description: A unique identifier for a single attempt of a single job. The value is unique to the current pipeline.

variables.name: System.JobName
variables.description: The name of the job, typically used for expressing dependencies and accessing output variables.

variables.name: System.OidcRequestUri
variables.description: Generate an `idToken` for authentication with Entra ID using OpenID Connect (OIDC). [Learn more](/azure/devops/release-notes/2024/sprint-240-update#pipelines-and-tasks-populate-variables-to-customize-workload-identity-federation-authentication).

variables.name: System.PhaseAttempt
variables.description:
Set to 1 the first time this phase is attempted, and increments every time the job is retried.

Note: "Phase" is a mostly redundant concept, which represents the design-time for a job (whereas job was the runtime version of a phase). The concept of *phase* is mostly removed from Azure Pipelines. Matrix and multi-config jobs are the only place where a phase is still distinct from a job. One phase can instantiate multiple jobs, which differ only in their inputs.

variables.name: System.PhaseDisplayName
variables.description: The human-readable name given to a phase.

variables.name: System.PhaseName
variables.description: A string-based identifier for a job, typically used for expressing dependencies and accessing output variables.

variables.name: System.PlanId
variables.description: A string-based identifier for a single pipeline run.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.IsFork
variables.description:
If the pull request is from a fork of the repository, this variable is set to `True`.

Otherwise, it's set to `False`.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.PullRequestId
variables.description: The ID of the pull request that caused this build. For example: `17`. (This variable is initialized only if the build ran because of a [Git PR affected by a branch policy](../../../repos/git/branch-policies.md#build-validation)).

variables.name: System.PullRequest.PullRequestNumber
variables.description: The number of the pull request that caused this build. This variable is populated for pull requests from GitHub that have a different pull request ID and pull request number. This variable is only available in a YAML pipeline if a branch policy affects the PR.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.targetBranchName
variables.description: The name of the target branch for a pull request. This variable can be used in a pipeline to conditionally execute tasks or steps based on the target branch of the pull request. For example, you might want to trigger a different set of tests or code analysis tools depending on the branch that the changes are being merged into.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.SourceBranch
variables.description: The branch that is being reviewed in a pull request. For example: `refs/heads/users/raisa/new-feature` for Azure Repos. (This variable is initialized only if the build ran because of a [Git PR affected by a branch policy](../../../repos/git/branch-policies.md#build-validation)). This variable is only available in a YAML pipeline if a branch policy affects the PR.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.SourceRepositoryUri
variables.description: The URL to the repo that contains the pull request. For example: `https://dev.azure.com/ouraccount/_git/OurProject`.

variables.name: System.PullRequest.TargetBranch
variables.description: The branch that is the target of a pull request. For example: `refs/heads/main` when your repository is in Azure Repos and `main` when your repository is in GitHub. This variable is initialized only if the build ran because of a [Git PR affected by a branch policy](../../../repos/git/branch-policies.md#build-validation). This variable is only available in a YAML pipeline if a branch policy affects the PR.

variables.name: System.StageAttempt
variables.description: Set to 1 the first time this stage is attempted, and increments every time the stage is retried.

variables.name: System.StageDisplayName
variables.description: The human-readable name given to a stage.

variables.name: System.StageName
variables.description: A string-based identifier for a stage, typically used for expressing dependencies and accessing output variables.

variables.name: System.TeamFoundationCollectionUri
variables.description:
The URI of the Azure DevOps organization or collection. For example: `https://dev.azure.com/fabrikamfiber/`.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: System.TeamProject
variables.description: The name of the project that contains this build.

variables.name: System.TeamProjectId
variables.description: The ID of the project that this build belongs to.

variables.name: System.TimelineId
variables.description: A string-based identifier for the execution details and logs of a single pipeline run.

variables.name: TF_BUILD
variables.description:
Set to `True` if a build task runs the script.

This variable is agent-scoped, and can be used as an environment variable in a script and as a parameter in a build task. It can't be used as part of the build number or as a version control tag.

variables.name: Checks.StageAttempt
variables.description:
Set to 1 the first time this stage is attempted, and increments every time the stage is retried.

This variable can only be used within an [approval or check](../../process/approvals.md) for an environment. For example, you could use `$(Checks.StageAttempt)` within an [Invoke REST API check](../../process/approvals.md#invoke-rest-api).

:::image type="content" source="../media/checks-stageattempt-var.png" alt-text="Add the stage attempt as a parameter.":::
